awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Single broadband detector from visible to near infrared using the spin Seebeck effect
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project will provide the medical field with a broad response detector capable of pairing with cheaper disease diagnostic tools for improved healthcare.  Currently, there is not a commercially available broadband detector that can capture visible light and near infrared light.  The Phase I SBIR effort will lead to an advanced detector capable of spanning this light range and fulfilling this unmet need.  As a commercial product, this detector can be used in multiple commercial sectors including unmanned vehicles, the medical field, and for the defense and security of the nation.  For example, in the medical field the ideal light for tissue penetration is between visible and near infrared.  The detector developed in this project would permit optical scans of human bodies for disease diagnosis.  The optical scan will provide a cheaper and safer alternative in comparison to expensive MRI technology and high-energy sources, such as x-rays, that result in radiological exposure.  The size of the global medical imaging market is currently valued at $16 billion and the proposed work would help healthcare services in rural areas have access to optical diagnosing services.

Semiconductor-based detectors are limited to absorbing photons whose energy is equal to or slightly greater than the electronic band gap of the semiconductor.  As a result, there is not a commercially available detector that can span 400-2200nm with fast detection.  The expected outcome of this project is a single broadband detector, based off of the quantum spin Seebeck effect to generate a spin current, that can span 400-2200nm with a flat quantum efficiency and a high response time.  The quantum efficiency (QE) of the patent-protected detector is almost three orders of magnitude lower than semiconductor-based detectors and the largest portion of the project is devoted to improving the QE to commercial levels.  The project will accomplish the following goals: 1) prove the feasibility of increasing the quantum efficiency by two orders of magnitude, 2) make a readout circuit board, 3) show detector capabilities through building a benchtop-working prototype, and 4) design a compact prototype to be built during Phase II. As a commercial product, this detector can be used in unmanned vehicles, in the medical field, and for the defense and security of the nation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
SLD Photonics’ Phase I project aimed at significantly improving the efficiency of a broadband quantum spin-based detector by almost 10,000%.  This innovation is rooted in advancing discovery and understanding of science as it came from research performed under academic research at the University of Wyoming.  Over the course of the Phase I effort, SLD Photonics conducted a series of experiments and collaborations, resulting in substantial advancements in quantum spin-based detector performance and functionality.

The primary objective of the Phase I effort was to increase the efficiency of the broadband detector by two orders of magnitude (10,000%). This ambitious goal drove the research team to explore various avenues for improvement, including modifications to the platinum film thickness, enhancements in spin coupling, and optimization of spin current through topological features. Through meticulous experimentation and analysis, SLD Photonics successfully achieved a significant increase in efficiency, marking a substantial leap forward in spin Seebeck-based detector technology.  Currently, there is not a commercially available single detector, with fast detection, that can span visible to near infrared.  During the Phase I effort it was shown that the spin-based detector can fill this unmet customer/market need.

Collaboration played a crucial role in the project's success, particularly with Snowy Range Design (SRD). Together, SLD Photonics and SRD designed and developed a specialized circuit board tailored for reading out signals from the quantum spin detector. Iterative improvements to the circuit board design, coupled with advancements in noise reduction and signal amplification, culminated in the creation of a highly efficient and reliable detection system.

The development of a benchtop working prototype further facilitated the research efforts, providing a platform for consistent measurements and streamlined experimentation. This prototype not only improved the efficiency of data collection but also enhanced the reproducibility of results, laying a solid foundation for future research and development endeavors.

Key findings from the Phase I project shed light on the intricate relationship between a radial spin Seebeck-effect and device responsivity. Through meticulous experimentation and analysis, the research team identified critical factors influencing signal strength and successfully mitigated challenges such as poor spin coupling and inconsistent signal distribution across the detector's active region.

Moreover, efforts were made to quantify the bandwidth of the detector, revealing impressive response times that surpassed those of traditional silicon-based detectors by a significant margin. This breakthrough discovery holds immense promise for applications requiring high-speed data transmission, positioning the quantum spin-based detector as a game-changer in the field of optical communications.

Despite encountering challenges such as increased substrate costs and equipment malfunctions, the Phase I project achieved its primary objective of enhancing detector efficiency by two orders of magnitude. This milestone not only validates the feasibility of the quantum spin-based detector but also underscores its commercial potential in various industries.

The Phase II prototype design at the conclusion of the Phase I effort focused on refining the quantum spin-based detector for commercialization, with particular emphasis on protective coatings and housing designs. Additionally, ongoing exploration of fabrication methods and strategic partnerships will further accelerate the advancement of detector technology, paving the way for broader adoption and integration into real-world applications.
